Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Laser 4D light field thermoreflectance (TR) imaging for non-intrusive high accuracy temperature measurement of 3D targets with high spatial and high temporal resolutions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator will develop a technique to determine the temperature distribution on a three-dimensional (3D) surface or object. The technique is similar to 3D photography, with the added and much more complicated challenge in mapping out the temperature. A camera with an array of micro-sized lenses will be aimed at the object. Because at different angles these lenses project the images, the effect of three dimensions is achieved. At the same time the intensities of the light reflected from various points of the surface is related to temperatures, the temperature on the 3D surface can be determined. The PI will also involve high school teachers, especially those from schools with high minority population, in addition to supervising graduate and undergraduate students.

The proposed study will create a microlens array (MLA) for thermal imaging, numerical algorithms to extract thermal information, and determination of transient 3D temperature profiles of LED packages during operating conditions and in transient state. The author will apply an approach known as 4D light field imaging, which enables imaging of 3D surfaces by the array of lenses, each having a different perspective on the object, to project images of the target (i.e., plenoptic images) onto a CCD sensor. The 3D image of the surfaces can then be reconstructed from the multiple perspectives, using an algorithm previously developed by the PI. Based on the temperature-dependent reflectivity and the reflected light intensity of the surfaces (i.e., their thermoreflectance), temperature changes can be identified. The proposed technique can achieve high accuracy (~ 10 mK), high spatial resolutions (~ half of light wavelength; i.e. diffraction-limited), and nano-second temporal resolutions. The technique can therefore be used for steady, quasi-steady, and transient state thermal imaging, enabling a wide range of applications including extreme conditions, light emitting diodes (LEDs) and laser diodes (LDs).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Temperature measurement is not only crucial in understanding the thermal transport process but also important in defect inspections of different micro/macro devices. Traditional temperature measurements require point-to-point mechanical contacts, which can disturb the operation of devices especially when their sizes are small. Based on this understanding, non-intrusive optical methods become popular alternatives for temperature measurements in the recent decades. In addition to point-to-point temperature measurements, optical based methods can achieve 2D/3D surface temperature measurements in one measurement (i.e., thermal imaging) if 2D/3D optical imaging methods are integrated in the optical based temperature measurements.

Two main groups of 2D thermal imaging have been developed and adopted in different scientific and industrial applications, namely, infrared (IR) thermal imaging and thermoreflectance (TR) imaging. IR imaging, compared with TR imaging, provides lower time response and temperature resolution. Therefore, we focused on TR imaging in this study. There are two main bottlenecks in current TR imaging, which are (a) sensitive to the target movement especially for microscale targets, and (b) applied for 2D surfaces only. To solve these two bottlenecks, the following research activities are conducted and achieved during the project years.

  1. Established a general  experimental scheme that can manipulate most light sources to provide highly uniform (99% uniformity or above) illumination (fig. 1).
  2. Established a two wavelengths thermoreflectance scheme (compared with traditional single wavelength scheme) to achieve high resolution non-intrusive surface temperature measurement of microscale target without worrying the target movement especially due to thermal expansions. Note that this two wavelengths TR scheme requires highly uniform illumination sources (fig. 2).
  3. Established a non-intrusive 3D surface temperature measurement scheme based on 4D light field thermoreflectance imaging (fig. 3, compared with traditional 2D optical imaging)

Intellectual Merit: Our outcomes in scientific knowledge contributions include: (1) development of an iterative correction scheme to generate highly uniform illumination from different light sources which is not feasible previously in small research labs; (2) integrated two different wavelengths highly uniform illuminations simultaneously during TR imaging, which not only can improve the temperature resolution in TR imaging but also can prevent effects of target movements during the TR imaging; (3) development of 4D light field thermoreflectance imaging for high accuracy temperature measurement of 3D targets. Note that even though thermoreflectance is focused in this study, the obtained knowledge can be extended to other thermal imaging based on 4D light field photography. 

Broader Impacts: The new 2D/3D TR imaging methods developed in this study for non-intrusive temperature measurement of 2D/3D surfaces, have potential to become standard techniques to identify the thermal energy transport in versatile macro/micro devices/structures. Also, more efficient thermal management for high power LED/laser diode in compact packages can be achieved based on the determined temperature profiles in LED/laser diode as functions of design/operating conditions with these new TR techniques. The outcomes of educational activities of this project include: (1) Mentoring high school teachers on topics of optical/thermal experiments and simulations; (2) Mentoring undergraduate and graduate students on 2D/3D/4D optical experiments and experimental/theoretical study of thermal energy transport in micro devices; (3) Enhancing curriculum of engineering laboratory and undergraduate/graduate level heat transfer courses; and (4) Disseminating results through conference participation and journal publications.
